paper.title: Financial communities
paper.abstract: Postings on Internet discussion boards provide an unusual opportunity to explore the sociological mechanics underlying the impounding of information into stock prices and to examine any implications for portfolio construction. Graph-theoretic techniques applied to contacts across the web network of stock discussion allow classification of stocks into two types: communities of connected stocks, and disconnected stocks. Connected stocks outperform others in a risk-adjusted sense. Adopting the concept of centrality from the sociology literature reveals that stocks with high centrality covary more with other stocks, suggesting greater analyst scrutiny. Classifying stocks into financial communities provides a novel way to look at risk-return trade-offs and to direct analyst attention, and offers new diversification insights for portfolio managers.

domain_result.justification: 该论文的核心技术是使用图论技术对股票进行分类，并探讨了这些分类如何影响风险调整后的表现和多样化策略，这直接应用于投资组合管理的领域。
